user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
- test_code: a modified lfs_file_read code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/53.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If the MISRA C rule is not violated, you can just return an empty string for the test code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of lfs_file_read as much as possible.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_read:
```c
lfs_ssize_t lfs_file_read(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file,
        void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_read(%p, %p, %p, %"PRIu32")",
            (void*)lfs, (void*)file, buffer, size);
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    lfs_ssize_t res = lfs_file_read_(lfs, file, buffer, size);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_read -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_file_read:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
...
static lfs_ssize_t lfs_file_read_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file,
        void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    LFS_ASSERT((file->flags & LFS_O_RDONLY) == LFS_O_RDONLY);

#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_WRITING) {
        // flush out any writes
        int err = lfs_file_flush(lfs, file);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }
#endif

    return lfs_file_flushedread(lfs, file, buffer, size);
}
</additional code>
Judge whether the above lfs_file_read code violates the rule 17.8 or not.
scenario: No violation: the function does not modify any of its parameter variables (no assignments to lfs, file, buffer, or size). It only passes pointer parameters to other functions and invokes macros that do not alter the parameter variables themselves. Modifying the object pointed to (via called functions) is permitted by the rule.
